title: How do people view death? - Quora

response.answer_text: I'm not sure,but I prefer to totally put it out of mine because I spoke to my grandmother on a Thursday afternoon after work in 2006 when she was dying of liver cancer in a palliative care unit my auntie who works in aged care put her into. I was crying because I knew it was the very last time I was ever going to speak to her & we were very close,the next day work finished at midday & my mother rang me up & said that she didn't have very long to live. I was in a mad rush to get to the palliative care unit & very worried I wouldn't see her alive ever again, the woman at the reception desk told me that she died at about after 11 am. So our family all got there & surrounded her dead body to grieve & to say our goodbyes,it was very sad just to see her lifeless body just lay there, she was no longer our Nan,just a body !!!! A week later,we went to her funeral on a Friday which went for 1/2 an hour then her body & coffin was taken away to be cremated, after that, we went to the bowling club for her wake. I was shaken by the whole ordeal & I took the Monday off work to get over the funeral. So,that's my thoughts on what death is to me !!!!

If I do good, my death will be good and I will be in heaven as Allaah has promised, and if my deeds have wronged me, I will be in hell. All these processes of life like education, marriage etc will all ultimately lead to death. So the end is basically death. What excites me is however that we are promised a perfect life afterwards provided we do not fail this test of life. And since it is Almighty’s promise so it has materialize. I have dream about that life is going to be something like this one but with perfection. So take out all that is troublesome and that is how life is going to be in the hereafter. To achieve this feat however we have to go thru lots of tests and trials, as Allaah says in Qur’aan that: “Do the people think that they will be left to say, “We believe” and they will not be tried?” (29:2) Death, a conundrum Allaah has left for those who believe; those who have firm faith in Allaah knows that His promise is true. Everybody shall be held accountable of his own doing. Be very very excited about meeting the Lord but be very very prepared for it, for Him is our Creator. He has given the clear view of hell and heaven. So there is no doubt about what it is going to be. What the real worry is that which side we end at. Fingers crossed while efforts on its way! P.S.: I am excited about it but I am so under-prepared.

I think the majority of people are afraid of it, mostly because it is a mystery and fear often follows something a person doesn’t/ can’t understand (fear of the unknown). I know this… I spent sometime working with patients/clients in a hospital as well as hospice and from my observation it’s not something to fear. I had one patient stating “ There he is, he is right there.” and peacefully died. Seemed like most of the deaths especially on hospice were peaceful and many expressed seeing someone or something coming (that was unseen) or there with them. My father-in-law passed away four years ago. He was on life support but still conscious, and he made the decision himself to be taken off life support. The whole family was there and he was fully conscious when he was removed . His last words were “This isn’t so bad.”

Depending on one’s culture and upbringing, and by the time one reaches the age of 18, he or she will have an idea of how to deal with death. Or at least how they view death. For some, their culture will have the biggest influence on what death is and how they will approach it. Different nations, cultures, peoples and religions will have a different view of a person’s passing. Some view it more as a transition, while other view it as the end of one’s journey. Others rejoice of one’s death, others pray and mourn the passing of a beloved. But one thing is certain, death is our final graduation in life. Not one is immortal and we cannot foresee when we will be passing. Of course there’s the act of ending one’s own life. Even for those people who’d committed suicide, their view of death might have influenced their action to take their own.

As I don’t believe in any sort of afterlife, in my view death is the ultimate end of me. There is absolutely nothing after it. No more lives, no heaven, no higher consciousness, no level-ups. So my perception of my existence looks like this:  On the other hand when I die my body will give possibility for new life to grow: grass, trees, worms and such. I get recycled in this extremely complex ecosystem that has been on Earth for hundreds of millions of years, and hopefully will be here for several hundreds of millions more. So, in a sense, despite the lack of any religious beliefs, I know that I AM part of something bigger than me and upon death I enter this circulation of life. It makes it a tiny bit less heavy to bear the thought of me not being around anymore.

I view death as something scary. Just the fact that we don’t know what will happen when we die is scary. Is it the end plain and simple? Are we reincarnated into another being? Or is there some sort of after life? We don’t know. And as much as I’d love to know, I think it would be best if we didn’t know. I’d rather just wait until it happens to find out. If there is an afterlife, then yay! I get to “live” longer somehow. If there isn’t, then it wouldn’t matter since I wouldn’t really exist anymore. But, I’m hopeful that there’s an afterlife. Whether that’s the Heaven we’re told about, or something completely different.

The difference between life after death and the whole death experience itself is quite distinct for me.....On the one side I don't actually fear the other side ..cold dark....nothingness. I mean can't be that bad coz no one has come back from it....But the whole mystery of when and how is what I insanely fear....Will I have accomplished something for my family....How painful/painless will it be? A lot of young honest hearted people I know have just been dying around me and at that point its really sad to see how much more they could have achieved if given a little more timeCould it have been easier if we had the choice to choose when and how???????????

Death is the only certainty in human life. Humans are fragile, phsyically, mentally and emotionally. All these vulnerabilities make life a very tortuous experience. But, despite all the trouble, all the joy that we experience, death is the common denomination in all our lives. Life has some meaning to it only because we know that someday, it will have to end. And we try to live, to do all we can to truly live, before we pass on. Death adds some meaning to life.

Totally depends on how you lived your life and did you really, really, really actually believe in your God. Little things like that are why I`m not a believer. I can`t believe that a "loving God" would send an otherwise righteous, saintly person to hell just because he hadn`t heard about your God, or simply didn`t believe there actually is a God. Why does one have to be "God fearing" in order to get into some heaven? I believe that the 10 Commandments (most of them) are good things and I`ve pretty much lived my life by them. I`m a good person and I`ve always believed in the "Golden Rule", but if I`m wrong and God does exist, I will burn in the eternal pit of fire, etc. Bull Crap.

Death is mystery! No one knows what happens after death. No one ever came back to share their experience. We only have religious scripts about the afterlife. They are more or less same. The promise of heaven and hell. Sometimes death feels like escape from the suffering of worldly life. It is eternal rest. Becoming nothing from being something. Yeah very scary but its the only truth we know.

Which Theology? The fact is though that most theologies are pretty light on detail regarding our continuing existence. People who have had near death experiences can give you a glimpse but it is generally only of the “Reception Area”. The world of Spirit is a very very large and varied place with many levels and sub levels. Most descriptions will therefore be quite limited and will not show that particular souls final destination. The good news is that wherever you end up (Birds of a feather flock together!) you can work you way up by your prayers and actions.

The ultimate truth, which is known by all yet feared and denied. If you found out you were dying would you be nicer, love more, try something new? Well, you are. We all are. Accepting death before it arrives, gives birth to a second life in us making us more capable and willing to take risks and well..live.

The scariest thing is not being able to see past dying. It is the same before we were born we can't remember how it felt because we didn't exist, I believe it's the same when we pass. As we are living we are in the now, the future is as scary as dying because we will become old and fragile and we all know the inevitable and I sometimes think why do we even try to enjoy this life when we will one day be forgotten all together. Still every day we live until the last, I don't think we should overthink it nor ignore it just appreciate the sun, the wind, nature, your family and everything you care for, that's what life is about.
